abstract.text: Defines the behavior of a timed event, known as a “fuse”, scheduled to occur
after a specific number of game turns.

Handles the “TURN ON” command, allowing the player to activate items that are
considered devices (e.g., light sources).
Represents stylistic hints for text output.

to a
A registry to hold dynamically computed logic (getters) and validation rules (setters/validators)
for item and location attributes.
Handles the “INSERT
INTO/IN
” command, allowing the player
to place an item they are holding into an open container item.
Handles the “WEAR” command and its synonyms (e.g., “DON”), allowing the player to
equip an item that is wearable.

Handles the “DEBUG” command, providing a way for game developers to inspect the
internal state of game entities during development and testing.
Defines the interface for all input and output operations within the Gnusto game engine.

and its active instance
within the game state.
Defines the blueprint for handling a specific game verb (e.g., “take”, “open”, “go”).

’s
method.
Represents an interactive object or entity within the game world, such as a brass lantern,
a rusty key, a treasure chest, or even a non-player character (NPC).

) and potentially other extensible game elements.
Determines visibility and reachability of items and locations based on game state,
primarily considering light conditions.

with
additional game-specific information before an action is handled.

A standard, ZIL-inspired implementation of the
protocol, designed to
interpret player input in a manner reminiscent of classic text-adventure games.
Handles the “EXAMINE” command and its synonyms (e.g., “LOOK AT”, “DESCRIBE”), providing
a detailed description of a specified item or the player.
Represents cardinal and other directions used for navigation and spatial representation.
Represents the specific moments or triggers that can activate a
Handles the “CLOSE” command, allowing the player to close an item that is openable
and currently open.
Represents conditions that a noun phrase (representing a direct or indirect object)
must meet to successfully match a
during command parsing.
Represents the complete, mutable state of the game world at a given point in time.
Handles the “DROP” command and its synonyms (e.g., “PUT DOWN”), allowing the player
to release an item they are currently holding into their current location.
A container for custom game logic that responds to specific events occurring in relation
to an
Represents a reference to a game entity, which can be an item, a location, or the player.
This provides a type-safe way to specify the target of a command.
Handles the “THINK ABOUT” command, allowing the player to ponder an item or themselves.
This is a more introspective action, often resulting in a generic or humorous response.
A unique identifier for a piece of contextual data relevant to an action.
Handles the “LOCK
WITH
” command, allowing the player
to lock a lockable item using a key.
A type-safe, unique identifier for a
and its active instance
(timer) within the game state.
Handles the “OPEN” command, allowing the player to open an item that is openable,
not locked, and not already open.
Defines a specific grammatical pattern or syntax that a player’s command can match
for a particular verb.
Handles the “PUT
ON
” command, allowing the player
to place an item they are holding onto a surface item.
Enumerates the distinct categories of side effects that can be triggered within the game.
Handles the “REMOVE” command and its synonyms (e.g., “DOFF”, “TAKE OFF”), allowing the
player to unequip an item they are currently wearing.
Handles the “TAKE” command and its synonyms (e.g., “GET”), allowing the player to pick up
an item and add it to their inventory.

to another in a specific
Handles the “UNLOCK
WITH
” command, allowing the player
to unlock a lockable item using a key.
Represents the type of a token expected at a specific position within a
’s pattern.
A type-safe enumeration that represents the various kinds of values that game state
properties can hold.
Represents a distinct place or room within the game world that the player can visit.
Represents a recognized verb in the game’s command vocabulary.
Represents a structured and validated player command, ready for the
to execute.
Holds the game’s vocabulary, mapping words to game entities and concepts.
Enumerates errors that can occur during the command parsing phase.
A protocol for types that group together the definitions for a specific area or region
of the game world, including its locations, items, and any associated event handlers.
Defines the interface for turning raw player input strings into structured
objects that the
can understand and process.

for an item.
A unique identifier for a standard or dynamic property within the game.
Handles the “READ” command, allowing the player to attempt to read text from an item.
A basic implementation of
that interacts with the standard console
(standard input and standard output).
A structure holding essential, game-wide constant values that define fundamental
aspects of the interactive fiction game, such as its title, introduction, and scoring.
Represents an attribute of a game object.
Represents an imperative action or an indirect consequence of a player’s command that
doesn’t directly modify a
property via a
A unique identifier for a verb within the game’s vocabulary.
Uniquely identifies a specific game entity (like an item, location, player, or a
timed event) whose state is being referenced or modified.
Handles the “TURN OFF” command, allowing the player to deactivate items that are
considered devices (e.g., light sources).
Uniquely identifies a specific piece of game state that can be dynamically read or modified.
Represents an attribute of an
Enumerates standard reasons why a game action might fail or be disallowed.
A type-safe, unique identifier for a
in the game world.
Defines the behavior of a background task or routine, known as a “daemon”,
that runs periodically at a specified frequency during the game.
Provides comprehensive contextual information for the execution of a game action.
Handles the “INVENTORY” command (and its common synonym “I”), displaying a list
of items currently carried by the player.
Represents a single, atomic proposed or applied modification to the game state.
Handles movement commands (e.g., “GO NORTH”, “NORTH”, “N”), allowing the player to navigate
between locations in the game world.
Represents the possible parents of an Item in the game hierarchy, determining its location
or containment state.
Handles the “TOUCH” command and its synonyms (e.g., “FEEL”, “RUB”, “PAT”), allowing the
player to physically interact with an item by touching it.
Defines the foundational structure and core components of a Gnusto-powered game.
Handles the “LOOK” command and its synonyms (e.g., “L”). It can also implicitly handle
“EXAMINE [ITEM]” logic if a direct object is provided with the LOOK command.
Represents the state of the player character within the game world.
